Booted up Hitman: Blood Money two days ago, after having not played it since 2006 or 2007.  Just beat it today.  Few things I found interesting about it:  - It's a 2006 PC port. You can run it at 4k just by making an ini edit, and it's flawless (doesn't break the UI or anything).  - As far as tech issues go, there was a bit of stuttering I fixed by going into the launcher and enabling both of the SLI settings (even though I'm not on SLI), but after that, game ran like it was made for my system. Then a lot of newer games have all these compatability issues and such until they're patched... were the people who made this game just better at what they did? Or have engines become so massive and unwieldy that it's more likely that things are going to fail than work? Or a combination of both?  - I had no bugs whatsoever.  - It has a first-person and third-person view - I know games did it even sooner, but I still think it's weird how a game from 2006 had this feature, and then it was a 'big deal' when the GTAV re-release introduced a first-person mode.  - obviously the textures and lighting are a bit dated, but the game still looks great. I think it's almost the perfect balance between the awkward 3D years where I couldn't believe any of it was real because it was too ugly, and nowadays where everything that goes for this style is hyper-realistic and immersion breaking because of it. This game is actually better looking to me than a lot of modern games that have that hyper-realistic plastic-surgeon-with-OCD look.  - the music is still phenomenal, of course  - the game doesn't pester you or tell you explicitly how to do everything. There are a lot of hints on the lower difficulties (on the map), but if you want to play it as a proper stealth game, you have to figure out how all the pieces fit together on their own. It has a lot of space. The game is challenging in its own way, but due to the way it's all set up, it's actually relaxing to play. I'm not being yelled at or expected to be somewhere constantly or being given game information nonstop because the people who made it were afraid that if the game stopped talking to the player for 10 seconds I would shut it off and leave. I can just enjoy it without being nagged and feeling rushed along because of the 'look here, do this, look here, shoot this' mentality. It lets you play.  - the worst thing about it is some character model pop-in, like the game runs a lower-poly version of them in the distance and when you get close makes them proper (I don't think I would've noticed this during my PS2 playthrough when it was new, but on PC at high-res and everything cranked it's pretty obvious)  - To boot every level is its own theme. If any copy-paste is going on it's minimal. There's more variety in the levels in a five hour game than I even saw in DOOM. Blood Money is genuinely interesting to play and anyone who hasn't played it yet needs to get it over with and understand why most people rant about most games. Once you have the best of everything, there's just a bunch of s*** you wade through hoping to find another game like Blood Money.  - Probably the best thing about it - it doesn't overstay its welcome. I played it on Expert (hadn't played in a loooong time so why would I Pro?), and beat every level with a Ghost, Professional or Silent Assassin rating, in just over 5 hours. I did remember some of the levels, but for the most part, I was blind here. It's refreshing, because they could've gone longer, they could've recycled assets to stretch it out, but why? Why do games need to last 'forever'?  I did reinstall Absolution out of curiosity. I ran it at max settings except for FXAA (which only blurs the image). Even though the tech Absolution uses is way better, and the textures are obviously much higher res, the game isn't as nice to look at as Blood Money.   Tech isn't everything. But when you don't know how to make a good game (something that I think needs to be a natural talent, like writing a good song or a good script - a few people have it, most people don't), you can at least learn how to push tech. And I think those are the majority of people making games these days, which is why going back to Blood Money is... holy ♥♥♥♥... most games really *are* as bad as I think they are.  But Blood Money is a masterpiece.
Cons: Very minor bugs (Fiber wire victim's body spazzing out, ragdoll bugs etc.)  Pros: Everything else.

The definitive game in the Hitman series and a gem of the stealth genre.   +YOU GET TO BE A HITMAN +Intricate stealth mechanics +Unique disguise system with a wide assortment of interesting, practical, and funny outfits +Trademark Hitman dark humor +Lots of freedom in how you conduct missions and assassinate targets +Large, open, sandbox levels to explore with very interactive environments -A bit glitchy, but nothing game breaking  Blood Money is commonly regarded by fans as the pinnacle of the series. Polishing the gameplay set by previous entries, this masterpiece delivers some of the most unique stealth gameplay available. Hitman is the series that pioneered social stealth, the ability to “hide in plain sight”. The disguise system in Blood Money works great and it’s fun to try different disguises to figure out what works best for certain situations. There are so many memorable levels in Blood Money, and I still manage to find new ways to perform assassinations. Levels like A New Life, Curtains Down, and The House of Cards are works of art. In this game, there are many creative ways to dispatch your targets, more so than any other Hitman game. You can rig a piano to fall on someone’s head, you can blow up a photoshoot with some well placed mines while dressed as Santa Claus, you can silently garrote your target while disguised as a birthday clown. Those who played Absolution and are looking for a taste of what the old games were like should look no further than Blood Money. For its current price, this game is a steal. Without a doubt, this is the best stealth game I have ever played.

Hitman: Blood Money  I remember playing this game a long time ago and having a blast. Revisting it on Steam was very much worth it.   Positives:  + Agent 47 now has more choices than ever when taking out a target. This game is awesome, and leaps ahead of its predecessors. Each assassination has many, many different ways to be pursued, a lot more than Contracts, Silent Assassin or Codename 47. Feel like staging an accident at an opera? Head backstage and swap the prop gun for a real one, then blow the chandelier foundations up with explosives, so they drop on your 2nd target. How about taking out a target in FBI witness protection? The target is having a birthday party for his child, so you can incapacitate a clown and walk right through the front doors. Then slip into the sauna where a spare FBI suit is and strangle your target to death with fiber wire. This is just the tip of the iceberg. So much variety it's amazing - which also means HUGE replayability.  + Graphics are pretty damn good for 2006, they hold up really well for a decade old game.  + Story is cleverly interwovern between the assassination missions, revealing more of the plot as you progress. I found it to be quite interesting.  + Stealth is superb in this game. You're going to need disguises, be it a waiter, garbage man, chef, policeman or whatever is applicable for your plan. Certain areas are restriced to those with access, so you're going to need the right disguises or move silently to avoid guard patrols. Hiding bodies is crucial to success, and for the first time in the series these can be concealed in freezers boxes or long, wooden crates.   + How professionally you perform your hits impacts on your notoriety and how much money you earn. Cash can be spent on body armour and health upgrades or modifications for weapons like silencers, scopes and sights.   Mixed:  ~ A lot of Hitman: Blood Money's gameplay revolves around understanding guard patrol patterns, timing and then perfect execution (this is of course if you're trying to achieve the perfect assassination). On the higher difficulties like expert, only 3 saves are permitted each mission and it can actually be quite difficult, until you work out the patterns. This is both good and bad. On one hand, there's too much focus on the previously mentioned mechanics which are time consuming. It can take hours to get the hit just right, with minimal civilian and bodyguard casualties. You'll be reloading endlessly, trying new combinations or methods to find what works best. On the other hand, this is part of the reason the game shines - to be the best assassin you have to perform like the best assassin. You need to think ahead and be on top of your game. It's a double-edged sword.   Negatives:  - Controls are a bit awkward, takes time to get used to. Could have been more polished for sure, but it's just a matter of adaptation.    Overall Score: 9/10  Conclusion: Best Hitman game of the series. It has style, great visuals, smart level design and solid storytelling. Don't miss out on this game, it's only a few dollars on sale.

Blood Money is the 4th game in the Hitman franchise - released in 2006, 6 years before the next episode reached completion in development. It took IO Interactive quite a long time to develop the latest episode for the game industry's (probably) most famous assassin. As to what caused this postponement I do not know - perhaps the reception of Blood Money had been negative or somewhat mixed. My feelings about the game are only positive and I salute IO for making such an amazing, stealth-based action-adventure software that offers high replayability due to the various difficulty settings available.  Blood Money gives us a different setting in each mission. Hitman eliminates a gang on a riverboat in Mississippi, approaches a drug lord in Chile, takes down members of a rivaling organisation during a street festival, eliminates a sheikh in a casino in Vegas and more! Every level is very different from its predecessor - it requires different tactics and it is very important to pay attention to your surroundings, i.e. where the enemies are, what their patrolling route is, what disguises you need for them not to be able to recognise you etc. Attention to detail is top notch. The game looks good, runs well and has very decent voice acting. Music was composed by Jesper Kyd who later on presented us with the excellent score of Assassins Creed.  More than one solution exists to solve a mission. The game, therefore, is varied and offers replayability as some solutions require more finesse and while they offer you the easy way out (i.e. no violent encounters) the execution can hold you for hours. In fact, a higher difficulty setting allows you only to save fewer times so you really need to plan every move carefully. Higher difficulty levels yield you with extra money after the mission as the game offers no achievements. More money means better weapons and gadgets at your disposal. But if you prefer the stealth approach you will not purchase new weapons or upgrade your existing ones with the extra sum - you, instead, will use this to bribe key people to decrease your notoriety. Also, when you play the game for the first time, it is advisable to purchase information; information that helps you with the solution in each mission in the form of tips, personal messages.  In Hitman you need to obtain a disguise all the time to get past certain points in the level. While stealth-based games are many I do not recall any of these out there offering this option. In many cases you need to use more than one disguise and just to make the game more challenging you get extra money for reaching the extraction point in your tuxedo, how you originally started your mission. Even the story is interesting and has some surprises - just to mention the name of some locations towards the end of it would be a spoiler so you can find it out for yourselves.  Blood Money is an exceptionally good game. Absolution is the 'next-gen' version of Hitman - but if you don't mind playing a challenging and exciting game that is 6 years old Blood Money is for you.

The Hitman series has always been known for its mix of stealth and action gameplay, and this entry of the series is no different.  The game plot is revealed by a series of interview pieces with a retired police officer, in which he usually tells something about the death of a certain person that most people thought something (a different story to the public) and turns out it was something entirely different involving 47. At first these don't make much sense, but as you play the game, you start to see where the plot is going, there aren't many remarkable points on it with the exception of the ending (which is amazingly delivered), so no spoilers.  The gameplay of this game follows the tradition of the old entries of the series, which is a good thing since it is what makes this series unique: you receive a briefing showing the place, who you have to eliminate, the background story of said person/people, then you choose your starting equipment and you are ready to go. What makes the game unique is that you can play in a stealth approach: observing enemy patrols, finding out how to infiltrate certain places, and planning a way to get close enough to take out your target or even how to take them down from afar.  One of the main features of the game that is still intact is that 47 is still a master of disguises and has the ability to change his clothing in seconds (it may sound a little weird, but it explains how someone can do the stuff he pulls off), which in most cases is the only way to access certain locations in the game. For instance, only workers can enter a part of the opera house that is still being build, I mean, you can enter without disguise, but that will attract attention AND the guards of the place.  An addition made in this game, is that now 47 can move faster while sneaking, in previous games, it was hard and painful to sneak around because it was too slow. He can now throw coins around to lure people to someplace where them and 47 can have a more 'personal conversation' or simply use them to lure guards out of posts and such.  Although it is a stealth game, it is different from what the conventional stealth games are and play. In here, you don't use the darkness to hide, you use the people and your disguises, you can crouch behind something, but don't expect that to go unnoticed: people react to your actions, and someone sees you sneaking around or behind people, they will react properly.  It is weird that people only bother listening to YOUR footsteps. For instance, there's this guard walking with another close to him, he'll do his job normally, then later you take out one of the guards and take his place, the other guard WILL start looking back and perplexed stare at you. These things are a little annoying because it happens only with the player. Since you can't sneak all the time without calling unwanted attention, you have to adapt to survive, and having access to a plethora of ways to approach a place/person is what increases its replay value and makes it unique.  Also a new feature is the introduction of Accidents. 47 can now push people off rails, roofs, etc, or he can just knock them out and THEN throw them off such places. This adds even more different ways to complete the assignments. Since the money you earn is determined by your performance in the missions, things as killing innocent people or be seeing doing something suspect all count towards your final rating. If someone saw you, you CAN kill this people as a way to have no witnesses, but the game will not penalize you if you can make it look like an accident, this is a nice addition.  You can now also customize your weapons, like putting a silencer in your Baller pistols or SMG, or putting a more precise scope at your rifles. Upgrading equipment is also possible now, such as decreasing the time it takes to lockpick a door or increase the distance of where you must be to detonate your remote bombs.  A new possibility now in case things get hairy is the ability to take people as human shields. But besides the obvious purpose it also serves as a way to take someone faster to a certain place. For instance, instead of having to wait till the person is knocked down with the effect of some of your tranquilizer syringes and then drag them somewhere more discreet, you can grab then and 'quickly' get them elsewhere and THEN knock then out without worrying with the possibility of someone seeing you.  In the graphics department, the game handles very well, its attention to detail is remarkable and every place in the game looks convincing, from a suburban house to a rehabilitation clinic or a Mardi Gras parade.  The soundtrack in this game is amazing, it server to set the mood for the missions but also to tell the player of the current situation, if something goes wrong and you're about to get shot by the guards, you'll know before hand because of the song that will start playing. The voice acting is really good, David Bateson delivers a believable cold Agent 47 as always, and Vivienne McKee does a great job bringing the faceless Diana to life in her 'cold but sometimes caring' voice. The NPC's voices sometimes are goofy and funny but noticeable intended as a way to ease the tension in the game.  The big arsenal of weapons, equipments, and disguises give the player a lot of freedom to approach the missions. Being stealthy and infiltrating a place from the back or even the front, or simply go guns blazing, be certain that you can always surprise yourself when things DO work even when you try to be more creative.

While Hitman: Blood Money kind of has an odd start (I'm pretty sure the tutorial was more focused on showing you how cool they are for adding new features instead of actually teaching you the features), I think it definitely turns out to be a great game. I wouldn't say the game is very hard, but it does take strong attention-to-detail and overall good observation of people's walking movings and general behaviors to even reach your enemy. I currently haven't played any of the other games except Absolution, so I will just give pros and cons for a new person to the series rather than a Hitman veteran.  Pros:  - Solid execution that makes this game still fun 10 years later without feeling dated. - Great level design which gives you a choice in playstyle; it could be possible to beat one level 20 times, based on what traps, weapons, and disguises you use. - Fun levels which almost make you excited or scared based on your situation; all levels are truly entertaining. - Great introduction of storyline -- The game's story takes place in the present, tells you a little more about the story and Agent 47, and sends you in a non-linear flashback of one of Agent 47's hits. This allows you understand the gameplay and story easily, and learn about Agent 47's life. - Changes future difficulty of levels with Notoriety. Obviously, in real life, if you shot up a drug lord's factory, it would be all over the news, and people would eventually find out an idea of the guy who did it. Because this is in the game, people will eventually figure out who keeps killing these people, so you'll end up being hostile to guards before you even really start the mission. It makes you have to understand how to limit witnesses and having your cover blown. Luckily, you can reset things like this for paying money to fix it, but it's still a pain in the butt and would be easier to just stealth. - On another note, the game encourages you to do things in a somewhat subtle way, unlike the notoriety. If you drop your weapons or leave your suit behind, this can not only change notoriety a bit, but it costs money for the Agency to retrieve it, so you have to pay a fee. On top of this, killing civilians with no witnesses also costs a fee for obvious reasons. - Intelligent AI during missions. So many games I've played where AI ignore key things like blood trails that humans would clearly follow, but Hitman: Blood Money pretty much has it to where AI act as intelligent human beings.  Cons:  - Unfortunately, there are some weak points of the pros I described. A problem in the AI is that they ignore weapons dropped on the floor, this becomes really obvious in the 'Flatline' mission when you place your guns down. - The tutorial is pretty bad. - This being a game from 2006, there are parts that really make this game show its age and feels frustratingly dated, and kills a lot of the immersion. However, these parts I could count on one hand, and are very rare.  Overall, I strongly recommend this game, as I had a lot of fun and really experience something I hadn't felt before. This is the best Hitman game currently for sale. Obviously some of the controls and gameplay mechanics are a little dated, and the graphics are definitely showing their age, but the level design, options for dealing with each mission, and no-BS mission delivery system are all superb.  The levels are huge, freely roamable, and logical. Stealth is rewarded but if you're just trying to finish the game, outright violence works fine, too. As long as you get the job done.  Free of the goofy cartoonish personalities and faux-dramatic emotional story of Absolution, Blood Money's story takes a backseat to the actual mechanics of hunting people down and killing them. How you complete the job is up to you, as it should be. Plan your own route, choose your equipment, observe and recon before taking action.  The downsides: some of the controls take some getting used to, the AI has some unexpected behaviours (which usually result in them shooting you for some infraction you weren't aware carries the death penalty, such as forgetting to wear a costume to the costume party), and, in my opinion, some of the early-game unmodified weapons are just so poor that they are almost unuseable (the sniper rifle before it is upgraded, for example).  Still, if you like games of patience, skill, and outwitting, plus killing people, this is the purest form of Agent 47 currently available.  I am looking forward to Hitman 5 this year, which promises to undo many of the mistakes of Absolution, but I'll believe it when I see it.

I have played this game on every console I have owned that has had it on - my PS2, my Xbox 360, and now my computer. I have completed it on every difficult more times than I can count, and spent more hours on this game than any other single game I have ever played. That should really sufficiently convey how much I love this game, so let's break it down. Pros: Replayable - I certainly find it endlessly fun to replay a mission, even if I have got the highest ratings on it. Fun - Whether you play the levels seriously and try and be stealthy, or if you just want to fool around and go crazy, this game will fit either style. Tough - It can be unforgiving, especially on the higher difficulties. Purchasing Upgrades etc. - You can buy upgrades with money you earn on contracts. The better your rating, the more money. Notoriety - The worse you are and more witnesses you have, the higher this factor gets. This makes guards see through disguises and recognise you much more easily. You can pay bribes after missions to reduce this. Humour and secrets - A number of great jokes and hidden bonuses can be found  Cons: Story - A bit disjointed, but not bad overall really. Graphics - Dated but not the worst for its age Physics - Appalling ragdolls and other physics on explosions and fire, even for the time. Doesn't effect real enjoyment, however. Melee Weapons - You cannot take melee weapons with you out of missions - they are not added to your collection, I mean, so they cannot be chosen at the start of a mission either. Annoying bits with compulsory action: A duel, a chase after a big explosion, and a couple of other occassions take something away from the levels with them in if you are looking for a purest experience. AI - At times incredibly stupid and at others far too omniscient, the AI is very odd. When it comes to basic behaviour, moreover, it does not take many playthroughs to memorise a level and all of the NPC's patrols and routes. This can mean replays are just following a procedure you have found successful before.  Overall, however, a solid 9/10 - one of my favourite games, and the best in the franchise - play this and see how far Hitman Absolution fell.

Fantastic game, especially when considering it is nearly a decade old. I had played the first two games long ago and while I always loved the concept of the hitman series, there always seemed to be flaws in the series. Hitman: Blood Money more than the others I have played seems to come closer to the concept of the perfect assassination puzzle game. This is a true open level concept with a myriad ways to accomplish your end goal, a compelling ranking system which names you according to playing style and rewards your success with a clever pay structure built for replay. Add to this the many easter eggs and special scenes and Hitman: BM is a wonderful experience. There are a few flaws in this gem (saving/loading is lousy and the character models are dated) but the overall experience makes this game well worth a play through. 8/10  Pros: - Open level concept allows for many play-throughs and different play-styles - Level Design is second to none... even the weaker levels are well thought out and fun to play through - Reward/Newsprint system is fantastic motivator - Weapons are diverse and allow for a variety of kills - Puzzles within each level are fun and challenging - In-level jokes and hidden references are abundant - Final level (Requieum) is one of the better endings I've ever played   Cons: - Save/Load system is awful (the developers tried to enhance difficulty by limiting saves but it just doesn't add to the experience) - Controls are wonky and stiff compared to newer games (translates to a steeper learning curve) - Some of the gaurd response zones/pathing is a little too black and white which can, at times, hurt the immersion (i.e. Stand here and you are fine, but two feet to the left will cause a gaurd to shoot you) - Some of the weaker levels are towards the end of the game so there is less of a build-up then would have been preferred - Character models and graphics optimization shows the games age (though not as bad as you would expect)

This game may be older, but it is considered a cult classic to this day. The Hitman titles before this one are the perfect brew of quirky, challenging stealth and humor. However, this one is regarded as the best in the franchise because it not only had the elements of the first couple games, but implemented a disguise system, upgraded accident system and above all: unleashed the freedom of sandbox gameplay (something the newest title 'Absolution' did not particularily have).   Basic Overview: You are one of the world's best assassins who was created in a laboratory as a killing machine, plain and simple. Your alias: 47. You work for a smoke and mirrors agency under a mysterious woman named 'Diana' who provides you with targets and mission details. The targets are larger than life, often rediculous and have prices on their heads that can set any average joe up for the rest of his days. The cleaner the hit, the more money in it for you. Your shady bosses have some international pull so weapons and certain things can be planted on the job site to make your work easier. Other than that, you do how you see fit. You can go in there gunning if you think you're strong enough to overpower your target's security. If you don't fancy getting shot, you can sneak in wearing a disguise, infiltrate your mark's hideout, then give them the drop when nobody's looking. There's also the option of say, rigging a chandeliear to fall on somebody's noggin slap-stick style or making someone have an 'unfortunate accident' by falling over a railing. The possibilities are endless! However, whatever inconspicous things you do such as leaving evidence, getting seen by witnesses or getting your cover blown can effect how easily you're detected in future missions. You aren't the only one in the Blood Money game either, any job could be a set up! Are you willing to risk the odds for the payout?  Cons: The controls seem rather 'stiff' and not fluid, especially when moving slowly or pivoting on the spot. There are sometimes annoying glitches such as people falling through floors/doors/walls when pushed and alerting your enemies. The AI can be extremely unintelligent and rag-doll glitchy which can bring some comedy into the gameplay, however, they are crack shots and can be extremely unforgiving, especially when glitched within a close proximity to 47s character. This game is sometimes not compatible in default settings with certain hardware/Windows versions and may crash/not run at all, but a simple patch and or resolution change often fixes these issues. Some level design may seem lazy in parts, but it's still nice to explore your whole environment, which is part of the Hitman experience.   Overall: I give this game an 8.5/10 given it is one of the funest games I have ever played and I still play it from time to time. I reccomend this game if you like stealth games, but you want a hint of free rome and added options in there. If you like linear stealth action, I would recommend the next title in the franchise 'Absolution'. The next game, simply called 'Hitman' boasts it will bring the sandbox element back into its gameplay. I think anything like Absolution's systems with Blood Money's freedom it would be a win/win! Fingers crossed!

Hitman: Blood Money continues the trend set by Silent Assassin by making the game more accessible and less frustrating, while emphasizing cleanliness and stealth on the part of the player. This time around, 47 has some new gear that sticks around mission to mission, such as sedatives and poison that can be used on any food object, but the opportunities to use these new features feel very deliberate and pre-placed. In many ways, this sums up what Blood Money is all about: It's less a matter of coming up with your own, creative way to approach a situation, and more about finding all of the possibilities the developers have hidden away for you. As long as you approach the game like a puzzle - looking for weaknesses in the defenses of a given target - this is more interesting than limiting. The storyline and setting are fairly uninspired, however, especially compared to the previous games, and gives a definite air of 'different writers who didn't get it'. Still, for those looking to enjoy a competent and relatively easy social stealth game with some unique twists and awesome setpieces, this is the way to go.

No matter how future Hitman titles turn out, the series will remain a classic for those who enjoy the taste of stealth and some contract killing. With good music, diverse missions, and an interesting storyline, Blood Money returns Agent 47 to his roots and it is for certain my favorite title in the series thus far.
